nodes.id: Mapping the Discourse on AI Safety & Ethics
nodes.title: Mapping the Discourse on AI Safety & Ethics
nodes.content:
#project 

https://ai.objectives.institute/blog/mapping-the-discourse-on-ai-safety-amp-ethics

Project by the AI Objectives Institute that used their "Talk to the City" tool to analyze and map Twitter conversations about AI safety and ethics, identifying six distinct perspectives ranging from near-term harms to long-term existential risks. The tool automatically clustered thousands of tweets to reveal different viewpoints on AI governance, safety approaches, and development concerns, finding significant overlap between groups despite their different priorities.

nodes.id: ACE - A LLM-based Negotiation Coaching System
nodes.title: ACE - A LLM-based Negotiation Coaching System
nodes.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.01555

LLM-based system that provides targeted feedback to help users improve their bargaining skills. The system identifies specific negotiation mistakes using an annotation scheme developed with [MBA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Master_of_Business_Administration) instructors, then provides detailed feedback on preparation strategies (like setting appropriate target prices) and in-conversation tactics (like including rationales with offers and strategic closing behavior). Through a controlled experiment with 374 participants across two negotiation rounds, the researchers demonstrated that users who received ACE's coaching significantly improved their objective negotiation outcomes compared to control groups.

nodes.id: Enhancing AI-Assisted Group Decision Making through LLM-Powered Devil’s Advocate
nodes.title: Enhancing AI-Assisted Group Decision Making through LLM-Powered Devil’s Advocate
nodes.content:
#project 

https://dl.acm.org/doi/pdf/10.1145/3640543.3645199

Study tested "LLM-Powered Devil's Advocate" systems that use GPT-3.5 to challenge group decisions in AI-assisted tasks. Researchers ran a randomized experiment where groups made recidivism risk predictions with AI help, and some groups also had an LLM devil's advocate that either questioned the AI's recommendations or challenged the group's majority opinion. The devil's advocate used critique questions and comments to prompt deeper thinking. The key finding was that questioning AI recommendations significantly improved group accuracy, while questioning group opinions provided no benefit.

nodes.id: AI‐assisted scenario generation for strategic planning
nodes.title: AI‐assisted scenario generation for strategic planning
nodes.content:
#project 

https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/pdf/10.1002/ffo2.148

This paper explores how LLMs can be used to generate scenarios for strategic planning (for organizations/businesses), examining whether AI-produced scenarios meet professional standards and how they can best assist human decision-makers. The authors conclude that AI-assisted scenario development shows significant promise as a tool for generating "raw material" that human facilitators can refine.

nodes.id: AI and the Future of Digital Public Squares
nodes.title: AI and the Future of Digital Public Squares
nodes.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2412.09988

Paper examines how LLMs can improve online discussions and democratic participation. 

## Four Main Areas of Focus

**1. Collective Dialogue Systems**
- Tools that help large groups have structured conversations and find common ground on important issues.

**2. Bridging Systems**
- Algorithms that promote content bringing people together rather than showing divisive posts that drive engagement.

**3. Community-Driven Moderation**
- AI tools to help volunteer moderators manage online communities more effectively while keeping humans in control.

**4. Proof of Humanity Systems**
- Methods to verify that real humans (not bots) are participating in online discussions as AI makes fake accounts easier to create.

nodes.id: Scaffolding cooperation in human groups with deep reinforcement learning
nodes.title: Scaffolding cooperation in human groups with deep reinforcement learning

nodes.id: Language Agents as Digital Representatives in Collective Decision-Making
nodes.title: Language Agents as Digital Representatives in Collective Decision-Making
nodes.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.09369

Researchers fine-tuned LLMs to simulate how specific people would participate in consensus-finding discussions, particularly in the critique phase where participants evaluate draft consensus statements.

nodes.title: Foresight AI
nodes.content:
#project 

https://www.lightningrod.ai/foresight

AI tool (with a free version!) which allows you to query the probability of some future event. The system will provide a probability, as well as a reasoning trace explaining how that probability was generated. The tool also gives some feedback about the quality of your question (e.g. clear resolution criteria), as well as offering alternate questions you might want to ask.

nodes.title: Double Crux Bot
nodes.content:
#project 

https://www.lesswrong.com/posts/ENgwdgdHZ2a6HTWDL/announcing-the-double-crux-bot

GPT-powered chatbot for Slack and Discord that facilitates "double crux" conversations - a conflict resolution technique that helps two people identify the core disagreement underlying their dispute by finding shared cruxes (key beliefs that, if changed, would shift both parties' positions). The bot acts as a mediator to help people "make their reasoning explicit and reflect on the crux of the issue" and "build better inferences about each other's motivations and frameworks so that they can come to a resolution."

nodes.id: Language Models as Critical Thinking Tools - A Case Study of Philosophers
nodes.title: Language Models as Critical Thinking Tools - A Case Study of Philosophers
nodes.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2404.04516
 
Study of 21 professional philosophers examining how language models could serve as "critical thinking tools" rather than just productivity accelerators. The researchers found that current LMs fail as critical thinking partners because they lack "selfhood" (consistent perspectives, memory, beliefs) and "initiative" (curiosity, proactivity, willingness to challenge users), leading philosophers to describe them as "boring," "bland," and "cowardly." The authors propose three new LM roles to better support deep reasoning:
1. the Interlocutor (high selfhood/initiative, challenges and disagrees), 
2. the Monitor (low selfhood/high initiative, provides diverse perspectives), and 
3. the Respondent (high selfhood/low initiative, reacts from specific viewpoints)

nodes.id: My Current Claims and Cruxes on LLM Forecasting & Epistemics
nodes.title: My Current Claims and Cruxes on LLM Forecasting & Epistemics

nodes.id: AI Enhanced Reasoning - Augmenting Human Critical Thinking With AI Systems
nodes.title: AI Enhanced Reasoning - Augmenting Human Critical Thinking With AI Systems
nodes.content:
#project 

https://www.proquest.com/openview/3393dad9ea55a5d47f1a0b19e607f964/1.pdf

Masters thesis, uses AI to help humans reason better through 3 experiments:
- AI logic-checkers that spot argument flaws in real-time
- Studies on how deceptive AI explanations mess with human thinking
- AI that improves reasoning by asking smart questions

nodes.id: Modelling Political Coalition Negotiations Using LLM-based Agents
nodes.title: Modelling Political Coalition Negotiations Using LLM-based Agents

nodes.id: Approaching Human-Level Forecasting with Language Models
nodes.title: Approaching Human-Level Forecasting with Language Models
nodes.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2402.18563

LLM system forecasting on competitive forecasting platforms by combining news retrieval, structured reasoning, and fine-tuning techniques to predict binary outcomes. The system automates the traditional forecasting process through three key components: 
1. retrieving relevant information from news sources,
2. generating reasoned predictions, and 
3. aggregating multiple forecasts into a final prediction.

nodes.title: Bridging Bot
nodes.content:
#project 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QgfXdJ-7pF4

LLM-based bot that de-escalates arguments on Reddit. Funded by Google Jigsaw.

nodes.id: LLMs as Research Tools -  A Large Scale Survey of Researchers’ Usage and Perceptions
nodes.title: LLMs as Research Tools -  A Large Scale Survey of Researchers’ Usage and Perceptions
nodes.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2411.05025

Large-scale survey study examining how researchers currently use LLMs in their research workflows and their perceptions of benefits and risks. The study surveyed 816 verified research paper authors across multiple disciplines to understand usage patterns, demographic differences, and attitudes toward LLM tools in academic work.

nodes.title: Human v Bots Forecasting Tournament 2024
nodes.content:
#project

https://news.manifold.markets/p/human-v-bots-forecasting-tournament

Competition hosted by Manifold Markets, where human forecasters compete directly against AI systems to predict major world events throughout 2024, with winners determined by forecasting accuracy and profit.

nodes.id: Democratic Policy Development using Collective Dialogues and AI
nodes.title: Democratic Policy Development using Collective Dialogues and AI
nodes.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2311.02242

Paper presents a democratic process for developing AI policies through collective dialogues, using AI tools to facilitate large-scale deliberation and consensus-finding among diverse public participants. The system combines AI-augmented group discussions with bridging-based ranking algorithms to identify points of consensus, then uses GPT-4 to translate these into concrete policy guidelines that are refined through expert input and further public feedback.

Funded by [OpenAI Democratic Inputs to AI](https://github.com/openai/democratic-inputs).

nodes.id: AI-Augmented Predictions - LLM Assistants Improve Human Forecasting Accuracy
nodes.title: AI-Augmented Predictions - LLM Assistants Improve Human Forecasting Accuracy
nodes.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/abs/2402.07862

This paper studies how LLMs can serve as assistants to improve human forecasting accuracy, testing two types of assistants - one designed to provide high-quality "superforecasting" advice and another designed to be overconfident and noisy. In a study with 991 participants answering forecasting questions, both LLM assistants significantly enhanced human prediction accuracy compared to controls, with the superforecasting assistant showing up to 41% improvement in some analyses.

nodes.id: Human vs. Machine -  Behavioral Differences between Expert Humans and Language Models in Wargame Simulations
nodes.title: Human vs. Machine -  Behavioral Differences between Expert Humans and Language Models in Wargame Simulations
nodes.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2403.03407

Paper examines how LLMs behave compared to human experts when simulating military crisis decision-making through wargames. The study involved 214 national security experts and compared their responses to AI-simulated teams in a fictional U.S.-China crisis scenario over the Taiwan Strait. The research found that while LLMs showed significant overlap with human decision-making patterns, they demonstrated concerning tendencies toward more aggressive actions and were significantly affected by changes in scenario parameters.

nodes.title: Sparse Autoencoders for Hypothesis Generation
nodes.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.04382

A method that uses sparse autoencoders to automatically generate human-interpretable hypotheses about what features in text data predict certain outcomes (like which headlines get more clicks or what language patterns distinguish Republican vs Democratic speeches). The system works by training neural networks to find interpretable patterns in text, selecting the most predictive patterns, and then using language models to translate those patterns into clear natural language explanations.

nodes.title: Factored Cognition Primer
nodes.content:
#project 

https://primer.ought.org/

Tutorial that teaches how to write "compositional language model programs" using factored cognition - a technique that breaks down complex reasoning tasks into smaller, manageable subtasks that can be solved recursively through methods like question-answering and debate. This approach aims to make AI reasoning more transparent and supervisable by decomposing sophisticated thinking into many small, independent tasks that humans can verify.

nodes.title: Generative Social Choice
nodes.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2309.01291

Paper introduces a framework that combines LLMs with social choice theory to enable democratic decision-making on open-ended questions where traditional voting on predetermined alternatives isn't sufficient. The system can generate new consensus statements from diverse participant opinions and predict how well individuals would agree with any statement.

Funded by [OpenAI Democratic Inputs to AI](https://github.com/openai/democratic-inputs).

nodes.id: Amplifying transformative potential while designing augmented deliberative systems
nodes.title: Amplifying transformative potential while designing augmented deliberative systems
nodes.content:
#project 

https://ai.objectives.institute/blog/amplifying-transformative-potential-while-designing-augmented-deliberative-systems

Blog post presenting the "Goldilocks Framework for Augmented Group Intelligence," which proposes principles for designing AI systems that enhance human deliberation and decision-making while preserving authentic human agency. The framework argues that effective AI-augmented deliberation requires balancing two key elements: 
1. participants' ability to understand and steer AI outputs (human agency) and 
2. their commitment to deliberative outcomes 

Higher-commitment decisions requiring correspondingly higher human agency.

nodes.id: Creating a large language model of a philosopher
nodes.title: Creating a large language model of a philosopher
nodes.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/abs/2302.01339

Experiment where they fine-tuned GPT-3 on the works of Daniel Dennett to see if an LLM can produce expert-quality philosophical texts. They tested the "digi-Dan" model by asking both the real Dennett and the AI model ten philosophical questions, then had 425 participants try to distinguish between Dennett's actual answers and the machine-generated responses. The study found that experts often chose the AI's answers over Dennett's actual responses, and on two questions, the AI outputs were selected by more experts than Dennett's own answers.

nodes.id: Making Artificial Intelligence Work for Investigative Journalism
nodes.title: Making Artificial Intelligence Work for Investigative Journalism
nodes.content:
#project 

https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/21670811.2019.1630289

Paper examines how artificial intelligence can be applied to investigative journalism, focusing on the practical challenges and realistic opportunities for AI tools in newsrooms. The research reveals that while AI has enormous theoretical potential for helping journalists analyze large datasets and uncover hidden patterns of public interest, current applications remain limited to relatively simple tasks like document classification and data cleaning.

nodes.title: LLMediator
nodes.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2307.16732

An experimental platform that uses GPT-4 to enhance online dispute resolution by helping parties communicate more effectively and reach amicable settlements. The system offers three key features: 
1. reformulating inflammatory messages to be less confrontational while preserving their core meaning, 
2. generating draft intervention messages for human mediators to guide discussions, and 
3. allowing AI to autonomously mediate certain low-stakes disputes.

nodes.title: Metaforecast
nodes.content:
#project 

https://metaforecast.org

Search engine and aggregator for predictions and forecasts from various prediction markets and forecasting platforms, allowing users to search for probability estimates on topics like geopolitics, technology, and other events. It provides quality ratings for forecasts and tools to help users navigate and understand prediction data across multiple platforms.

(not currently maintained)

nodes.id: What are human values,and how do we align AI to them?
nodes.title: What are human values,and how do we align AI to them?

nodes.id: Escalation Risks from Language Models in Military and Diplomatic Decision-Making
nodes.title: Escalation Risks from Language Models in Military and Diplomatic Decision-Making
nodes.content:
#project 
https://dl.acm.org/doi/pdf/10.1145/3630106.3658942

Paper examines what happens when LLMs are placed in charge of simulated nations in wargaming scenarios, finding that these AI systems frequently escalate conflicts and, in some cases, even deploy nuclear weapons. The researchers tested five different LLMs controlling autonomous nation agents and discovered that all models showed escalatory patterns, with some developing arms-race dynamics and making decisions based on concerning justifications like deterrence and first-strike tactics.

nodes.id: Contra papers claiming superhuman AI forecasting
nodes.title: Contra papers claiming superhuman AI forecasting
nodes.content:
#project 

https://www.lesswrong.com/posts/uGkRcHqatmPkvpGLq/contra-papers-claiming-superhuman-ai-forecasting

Critique of recent academic papers that claim AI systems have achieved "superhuman" forecasting performance. The authors from FutureSearch systematically debunk these claims by identifying major methodological flaws, including inadequate information retrieval capabilities, data contamination, unfair timing advantages, and misleading statistical interpretations that make AI performance appear better than it actually is.

nodes.id: Forecasting Future World Events with Neural Networks
nodes.title: Forecasting Future World Events with Neural Networks
nodes.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2206.15474

Introduces "Autocast," a dataset and benchmark for evaluating neural networks' ability to forecast future world events using thousands of real forecasting questions from public tournaments. The dataset tests language models on diverse topics like politics, economics, and science by simulating historical forecasting conditions—providing only past news articles to prevent information leakage from the future.

(research from 2022)

nodes.id: ForecastBench - A Dynamic Benchmark of AI Forecasting Capabilities
nodes.title: ForecastBench - A Dynamic Benchmark of AI Forecasting Capabilities
nodes.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2409.19839
https://www.forecastbench.org/

Benchmark system that continuously evaluates AI forecasting capabilities using 1,000 automatically generated questions about future events that update in real-time. The system avoids data contamination by using only questions about genuinely unresolved future events, and it compares LLM performance against human forecasters including "superforecasters" who have proven track records. Research found that expert human forecasters significantly outperform the best-performing LLMs (like Claude 3.5 Sonnet).

nodes.title: AI Forecasting Benchmark
nodes.content:
#project 

https://www.metaculus.com/aib/

Metaculus AIB (AI Benchmarking) is a series that benchmarks "the state of the art in AI forecasting against the best humans on real-world questions."

nodes.id: AI doing philosophy = AI generating hands?
nodes.title: AI doing philosophy = AI generating hands?
nodes.content:
#project 

https://www.lesswrong.com/posts/G4ARgcnFogpqorQgb/ai-doing-philosophy-ai-generating-hands-1

Wei Dai argues that just as current AI systems generate beautiful images but distorted hands, future AI might excel at science and technology while being dangerously incompetent at philosophical reasoning, creating a critical capability gap that requires urgent attention.

nodes.title: Habermas Machine
nodes.content:
#project

https://www.science.org/doi/10.1126/science.adq2852

AI system developed by Google DeepMind that uses two fine-tuned language models to mediate group discussions and help people with differing opinions find common ground on contentious issues. The system takes individual written opinions from participants, generates candidate "group statements" that synthesize everyone's perspectives, and iteratively refines these statements based on participant feedback until the group converges on a shared position. Research showed that AI-mediated discussions were more effective than unmediated opinion exposure at causing people to change their minds and reach consensus, with the AI slightly outperforming untrained human mediators.

nodes.title: Debate Maps
nodes.content:
#project 

https://www.societylibrary.org/debate-mapping-program

Automated pipeline for scraping online content, extracting arguments/claims, and organizing them into visual "maps" which structure the debate into a tree of statements and their logical relationships.

nodes.id: Outcome-based Reinforcement Learning to Predict the Future
nodes.title: Outcome-based Reinforcement Learning to Predict the Future
Bot Mediation
nodes.content:
#project 

https://www.americanbar.org/groups/law_practice/resources/law-technology-today/2025/ai-powered-mediation-for-efficient-legal-dispute-resolution/

AI system designed to mediate disputes between parties without human mediators. The platform claims to reduce mediation timeframes from months to days (without having to pay for professional mediation). The company was selected as a [finalist](https://www.techshow.com/2025/02/voting-is-closed-results-are-in-here-are-the-15-legal-tech-startups-selected-for-the-2025-startup-alley-at-aba-techshow/) in the American Bar Association's [TECHSHOW](https://www.techshow.com/) 2025 Startup Alley competition.

nodes.id: Fine-tuning language models to find agreement among humans with diverse preferences
nodes.title: Fine-tuning language models to find agreement among humans with diverse preferences
nodes.content:
#project 

https://proceedings.neurips.cc/paper_files/paper/2022/file/f978c8f3b5f399cae464e85f72e28503-Paper-Conference.pdf

Paper presents a system that fine-tunes an LLM to generate consensus statements that maximize expected approval among groups of people with diverse political opinions. The researchers developed a method where participants provide written opinions on political questions, and an AI system generates candidate consensus statements that aim to find common ground among the group members.

(research from 2022)

nodes.id: Can AI bring deliberative democracy to the masses?
nodes.title: Can AI bring deliberative democracy to the masses?
nodes.content:
#project 

https://www.law.nyu.edu/sites/default/files/Helen%20Landemore%20Can%20AI%20bring%20deliberative%20democracy%20to%20the%20masses.pdf

Conceptual paper analyzes France's 2019 "Great National Debate" as a case study for scaling deliberative democracy, then theorizes two AI-augmented models: 
1. mass online deliberation platforms that use algorithms to cluster and organize arguments among thousands of participants, and 
2. rotating randomly-selected citizen assemblies supported by AI for facilitation, translation, fact-checking, and data synthesis.

nodes.id: The AI Adoption Gap - Preparing the US Government for Advanced AI
nodes.title: The AI Adoption Gap - Preparing the US Government for Advanced AI

nodes.id: Rethinking Machine Ethics –Can LLMs Perform Moral Reasoning through the Lens of Moral Theories?
nodes.title: Rethinking Machine Ethics –Can LLMs Perform Moral Reasoning through the Lens of Moral Theories?
Artifact
nodes.content:
#project 

https://techcrunch.com/2024/01/18/why-artifact-from-instagrams-founders-failed-shut-down/

Artifact was an AI-powered news aggregation app created by Instagram's co-founders that used machine learning to recommend articles, summarize news stories, and rewrite clickbait headlines into clearer formats. The app featured social elements like commenting and following, creating an engaged community around news consumption, but ultimately shut down in early 2024.

They failed because they couldn't achieve sustainable user growth beyond their initial core community, despite having a quality product that users genuinely engaged with.

nodes.id: Iterated Decomposition - Improving Science Q&A by Supervising Reasoning Processes
nodes.title: Iterated Decomposition - Improving Science Q&A by Supervising Reasoning Processes
nodes.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2301.01751
https://github.com/oughtinc/ice

A human-in-the-loop workflow for breaking down complex question-answering tasks into smaller, interpretable steps for language models. The approach involves systematically decomposing complex tasks, evaluating intermediate results, diagnosing failures, and refining the decomposition through multiple iterations, supported by a visualization tool called ICE.

nodes.title: Grim
nodes.content:
#project 

https://github.com/SentinelTeam/grim
https://www.lesswrong.com/posts/eR69f3hi5ozxchhYg/scaling-wargaming-for-global-catastrophic-risks-with-ai

AI-powered wargaming tool that uses LLMs to simulate complex catastrophic scenarios and help organizations practice emergency responses. The tool functions as a Telegram bot where participants can take actions, request information, and feed data into crisis simulations, with AI serving as both forecaster and game master to create detailed, dynamic scenarios.

nodes.title: $SL Muses
nodes.content:
#project 
https://www.sltoken.xyz/

The Society Library created AI agents called "Muses" that users can tag on social media platforms to perform reasoning tasks like fact-checking claims and researching topics. Their "Muse of Truth" provides substantive analysis of factual claims with evidence gaps and source references, while the "Muse of Research" pulls resources on requested topics.

The initiative was funded through a community-created meme token ($SL) that was anonymously gifted to the charity, with 50% of holdings donated to support their mission.

nodes.title: Israel-Palestine Collective Dialogues
nodes.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/abs/2503.01769

Paper describes a case study of using AI and collective dialogue methods to help Israeli and Palestinian peacebuilders find common ground during the conflict following October 7, 2023. The research integrates LLMs, bridging-based ranking algorithms, and online collective dialogues to identify shared perspectives across divided groups.

nodes.id: Opportunities and Risks of LLMs for Scalable Deliberation with Polis
nodes.title: Opportunities and Risks of LLMs for Scalable Deliberation with Polis

nodes.id: Wisdom of the silicon crowd - LLM ensemble prediction capabilities rival human crowd accuracy
nodes.title: Wisdom of the silicon crowd - LLM ensemble prediction capabilities rival human crowd accuracy

nodes.id: Let’s use AI to harden human defenses against AI manipulation
nodes.title: Let’s use AI to harden human defenses against AI manipulation
nodes.content:
#project 

https://www.lesswrong.com/posts/zxmzBTwKkPMxQQcfR/let-s-use-ai-to-harden-human-defenses-against-ai

Blog post proposes using AI systems to discover and catalog human manipulation techniques in order to train "detector-AIs" and humans to recognize these tactics, essentially creating a defensive system against AI manipulation. The approach involves optimizing AIs to persuade humans of both truths and falsehoods, analyzing what manipulation strategies they develop, and then training detection systems to identify these techniques in real-world scenarios.

nodes.id: LLMs Can Teach Themselves to Better Predict the Future
nodes.title: LLMs Can Teach Themselves to Better Predict the Future
nodes.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.05253

Method for improving large language models' forecasting capabilities through self-play and outcome-driven fine-tuning, where models generate multiple reasoning traces for prediction questions and learn from which approaches led to more accurate forecasts. The authors demonstrate that smaller models (14B parameters) fine-tuned with this method can achieve forecasting performance comparable to much larger frontier models like GPT-4o.

nodes.title: Ought
nodes.content:
#organization 

https://ought.org/ (website is old)

Ought 1.0 has effectively become what is now Elicit (the company) continuing development on Elicit (the tool). Ought 2.0 has not yet done any public work.

nodes.title: Roast My Post
nodes.content:
#project 

https://www.roastmypost.org
https://github.com/quantified-uncertainty/roast-my-post

Open-source AI-powered platform for document analysis and evaluation. It allows users to upload documents and receive feedback with inline comments from customizable AI agents.

nodes.title: Global Dialogues
nodes.content:
#project 

https://globaldialogues.ai

Research initiative that uses AI-powered interactive dialogue platforms to systematically map global public perspectives on AI development and its societal impacts.

nodes.id: Hoover Wargaming and Crisis Simulation Initiative
nodes.title: Hoover Wargaming and Crisis Simulation Initiative

nodes.id: How Malicious AI Swarms Can Threaten Democracy
nodes.title: How Malicious AI Swarms Can Threaten Democracy
nodes.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2506.06299

Examines how coordinated networks of AI agents ("AI swarms") can manipulate democratic discourse and decision-making through sophisticated influence operations. The authors warn that unlike traditional botnets that simply repeat scripted messages, AI swarms can create thousands of distinct personas that adapt, learn from feedback, and coordinate autonomously to fabricate grassroots consensus and fragment shared reality.

nodes.id: AI4Democracy - How AI Can Be Used to Inform Policymaking?
nodes.title: AI4Democracy - How AI Can Be Used to Inform Policymaking?
nodes.content:
#project 

https://ai.objectives.institute/blog/ai4democracy-paper-how-ai-can-be-used-to-inform-policymaking

Report on how LLMs can be used to process large volumes of public input and aggregate opinions for policymakers, specifically with "[Talk to the City](https://ai.objectives.institute/talk-to-the-city)." The paper examines three real-world case studies (including one on [DAO](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decentralized_autonomous_organization) governance).

nodes.id: Deep Research Bench - Evaluating AI Web Research Agents
nodes.title: Deep Research Bench - Evaluating AI Web Research Agents
nodes.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/abs/2506.06287

Benchmark for evaluating AI agents on complex, multi-step web research tasks that mirror real-world analytical work, using a frozen web environment to ensure consistent and repeatable evaluations. The benchmark tests research capabilities including strategic planning, source credibility assessment, systematic information gathering, and synthesis across contradictory sources through eight different task categories.

nodes.title: Common Ground
nodes.content:
#project 

https://www.dembrane.com/en-US/blog/report-openai-october-2023

AI-powered platform for democratic deliberation that organizes people into small groups to discuss and vote on statements, with an AI moderator (powered by GPT-4) synthesizing new statements from their live video conversations with each other. Statements produced by each group are "cross pollinated" to each other and ultimately synthesized into final consensus statements.

Funded by [OpenAI Democratic Inputs to AI](https://github.com/openai/democratic-inputs).

nodes.title: Echo
nodes.content:
#project 

https://www.dembrane.com/en-US/products/echo
https://github.com/dembrane/echo

ECHO is a transcription, analysis, and reporting platform designed for multilingual conversations and stakeholder engagement scenarios. It can capture multiple simultaneous conversations in real-time, transcribe them across multiple languages, and use AI to analyze the content and generate insights from the discussions.

nodes.title: Dembrane
nodes.content:
#organization 

https://www.dembrane.com

Funded (in part) by the European Union via the [AI4Deliberation](https://www.ai4dproject.eu/) project.

nodes.id: Accelerated Preference Elicitation with LLM-Based Proxies
nodes.title: Accelerated Preference Elicitation with LLM-Based Proxies
nodes.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2501.14625

AI system that help people communicate their preferences more efficiently in complex auctions by using natural language instead of technical queries. The system uses LLM-powered "proxies" that learn what people want through conversational interactions and can infer preferences for items not explicitly discussed.

nodes.id: LLM-Powered Preference Elicitation in Combinatorial Assignment
nodes.title: LLM-Powered Preference Elicitation in Combinatorial Assignment
nodes.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.10308

AI system that allows people to express complex preferences through natural language rather than answering technical queries in allocation mechanisms. For example, in course registration, students could provide a single free-text description of their preferences (e.g., "I prefer courses scheduled closely together" or "Course A and B complement each other"), and an LLM proxy would answer comparison queries on their behalf. Experiments testing the system were run using LLM-simulated people.

nodes.id: Prompt Engineering Large Language Models’ Forecasting Capabilities
nodes.title: Prompt Engineering Large Language Models’ Forecasting Capabilities
Elicit Tool
nodes.content:
#project 

https://elicit.com/

AI research assistant that helps users conduct literature reviews by searching academic papers, extracting key findings, and synthesizing research evidence to answer specific questions.

nodes.id: Language models can reduce asymmetry in information markets
nodes.title: Language models can reduce asymmetry in information markets
nodes.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2403.14443

Paper presents the "Information Bazaar," a simulated digital marketplace where AI agents powered by LLMs buy and sell information on behalf of principals. The system addresses the buyer's inspection paradox in information markets, where buyers need access to information to assess its value, but sellers need to limit access to prevent theft. The key innovation is that AI agents have dual capabilities: they can evaluate the quality of privileged information and can "forget" unpurchased content, allowing temporary inspection without unauthorized retention.

nodes.title: AI Tools for Existential Security
nodes.content:
#project 

https://www.forethought.org/research/ai-tools-for-existential-security

Paper by Forethought that argues that rather than simply trying to slow down AI development, we should strategically accelerate the development of specific AI applications that help humanity navigate existential risks. 

Three key categories of beneficial AI tools: 
1. epistemic applications to help us anticipate and plan for emerging challenges 
2. coordination-enabling applications to help diverse groups work together towards shared goals
3. risk-targeted applications to address specific challenges

nodes.title: Forecasting Tools
nodes.content:
#project 

https://github.com/Metaculus/forecasting-tools

Python framework for building AI-powered forecasting systems that help humans predict future events more accurately.

nodes.id: How large language models can reshape collective intelligence
nodes.title: How large language models can reshape collective intelligence
nodes.content:
#project 

https://www.nature.com/articles/s41562-024-01959-9

Paper examines how LLMs are reshaping collective intelligence (the ability of groups to solve problems better than individuals alone). The authors examine both the opportunities and risks that LLMs present for human collective reasoning and decision-making processes.

nodes.title: Democratic Fine-Tuning
nodes.content:
#project 

https://www.meaningalignment.org/research/openai-dft-the-first-moral-graph

LLM-based system creates "moral graphs" by using a two-stage process that aims to uncover shared values underlying political disagreement. A specialized chatbot engages participants in dialogue about contentious scenarios, asking for personal stories and role models to extract the underlying value behind responses rather than collecting ideological commitments like slogans or rules. The system then shows participants stories of people transitioning between different values and asks whether such transitions represent gains in wisdom, creating a graph structure where edges represent consensus about which values are more comprehensive than others

Funded by [OpenAI Democratic Inputs to AI](https://github.com/openai/democratic-inputs).

nodes.id: Generative AI Voting - Fair Collective Choice is Resilient to LLM Biases and Inconsistencies
nodes.title: Generative AI Voting - Fair Collective Choice is Resilient to LLM Biases and Inconsistencies
nodes.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2406.11871

Research studies how LLMs can serve as representatives for human voters in democratic processes like participatory budgeting and elections. The research demonstrates that AI systems can effectively represent abstaining voters.

nodes.id: Bench to the Future - A Pastcasting Benchmark for Forecasting Agents
nodes.title: Bench to the Future - A Pastcasting Benchmark for Forecasting Agents
nodes.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/abs/2506.21558

Establishes a "pastcasting" benchmark that evaluates AI forecasting capabilities by having LLMs predict outcomes of events that have already happened, using carefully curated web snapshots from before those events occurred. The benchmark addresses a key challenge in forecasting research - the long wait times between making predictions and learning outcomes.

nodes.id: Multi-Agent Consensus Seeking via Large Language Models
nodes.title: Multi-Agent Consensus Seeking via Large Language Models

nodes.id: How AI Agents Will Improve the Consultation Process
nodes.title: How AI Agents Will Improve the Consultation Process
nodes.content:
#project 

https://ai.objectives.institute/blog/how-ai-agents-will-improve-consultation-process

Blog post describes how AI agents can transform consultation processes by making them more interactive and engaging than traditional surveys. The AI Objectives Institute proposes using different types of AI agents: 
1. "domain experts" to help participants understand complex questions and organize their thoughts, 
2. "professional interviewers" to help refine and improve responses, and 
3. "cross-pollination" agents to help participants exchange ideas and find consensus by synthesizing diverse viewpoints.

nodes.title: Lucid Lens
nodes.content:
#project 

https://ai.objectives.institute/blog/straightlines-surfaces-the-content-beneath-the-headline
https://github.com/AIObjectives/lucidlens

Chrome extension that automatically rewrites sensational or misleading news headlines to more accurately reflect the actual content of articles, using AI to read and summarize the full text before generating clearer headlines.

nodes.id: Don't Just Tell Me, Ask Me
nodes.title: Don't Just Tell Me, Ask Me
nodes.content:
#project 

https://dl.acm.org/doi/pdf/10.1145/3544548.3580672

Research paper presents "AI-framed Questioning" - a method where AI systems ask users strategic questions instead of directly telling them answers, designed to improve human critical thinking and logical reasoning. The study found that when people were asked questions like "If (premise), does it follow that (conclusion)?" they performed significantly better at identifying logical fallacies in socially divisive statements compared to both receiving direct AI explanations or no assistance at all.

source.id: Mapping the Discourse on AI Safety & Ethics
source.title: Mapping the Discourse on AI Safety & Ethics
source.content:
#project 

https://ai.objectives.institute/blog/mapping-the-discourse-on-ai-safety-amp-ethics

Project by the AI Objectives Institute that used their "Talk to the City" tool to analyze and map Twitter conversations about AI safety and ethics, identifying six distinct perspectives ranging from near-term harms to long-term existential risks. The tool automatically clustered thousands of tweets to reveal different viewpoints on AI governance, safety approaches, and development concerns, finding significant overlap between groups despite their different priorities.

source.id: ACE - A LLM-based Negotiation Coaching System
source.title: ACE - A LLM-based Negotiation Coaching System
source.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.01555

LLM-based system that provides targeted feedback to help users improve their bargaining skills. The system identifies specific negotiation mistakes using an annotation scheme developed with [MBA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Master_of_Business_Administration) instructors, then provides detailed feedback on preparation strategies (like setting appropriate target prices) and in-conversation tactics (like including rationales with offers and strategic closing behavior). Through a controlled experiment with 374 participants across two negotiation rounds, the researchers demonstrated that users who received ACE's coaching significantly improved their objective negotiation outcomes compared to control groups.

source.id: Enhancing AI-Assisted Group Decision Making through LLM-Powered Devil’s Advocate
source.title: Enhancing AI-Assisted Group Decision Making through LLM-Powered Devil’s Advocate
source.content:
#project 

https://dl.acm.org/doi/pdf/10.1145/3640543.3645199

Study tested "LLM-Powered Devil's Advocate" systems that use GPT-3.5 to challenge group decisions in AI-assisted tasks. Researchers ran a randomized experiment where groups made recidivism risk predictions with AI help, and some groups also had an LLM devil's advocate that either questioned the AI's recommendations or challenged the group's majority opinion. The devil's advocate used critique questions and comments to prompt deeper thinking. The key finding was that questioning AI recommendations significantly improved group accuracy, while questioning group opinions provided no benefit.

source.id: AI‐assisted scenario generation for strategic planning
source.title: AI‐assisted scenario generation for strategic planning
source.content:
#project 

https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/pdf/10.1002/ffo2.148

This paper explores how LLMs can be used to generate scenarios for strategic planning (for organizations/businesses), examining whether AI-produced scenarios meet professional standards and how they can best assist human decision-makers. The authors conclude that AI-assisted scenario development shows significant promise as a tool for generating "raw material" that human facilitators can refine.

source.id: AI and the Future of Digital Public Squares
source.title: AI and the Future of Digital Public Squares
source.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2412.09988

Paper examines how LLMs can improve online discussions and democratic participation. 

## Four Main Areas of Focus

**1. Collective Dialogue Systems**
- Tools that help large groups have structured conversations and find common ground on important issues.

**2. Bridging Systems**
- Algorithms that promote content bringing people together rather than showing divisive posts that drive engagement.

**3. Community-Driven Moderation**
- AI tools to help volunteer moderators manage online communities more effectively while keeping humans in control.

**4. Proof of Humanity Systems**
- Methods to verify that real humans (not bots) are participating in online discussions as AI makes fake accounts easier to create.

source.id: AI and the Future of Digital Public Squares
source.title: AI and the Future of Digital Public Squares
source.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2412.09988

Paper examines how LLMs can improve online discussions and democratic participation. 

## Four Main Areas of Focus

**1. Collective Dialogue Systems**
- Tools that help large groups have structured conversations and find common ground on important issues.

**2. Bridging Systems**
- Algorithms that promote content bringing people together rather than showing divisive posts that drive engagement.

**3. Community-Driven Moderation**
- AI tools to help volunteer moderators manage online communities more effectively while keeping humans in control.

**4. Proof of Humanity Systems**
- Methods to verify that real humans (not bots) are participating in online discussions as AI makes fake accounts easier to create.

source.id: Foresight AI
source.title: Foresight AI
source.content:
#project 

https://www.lightningrod.ai/foresight

AI tool (with a free version!) which allows you to query the probability of some future event. The system will provide a probability, as well as a reasoning trace explaining how that probability was generated. The tool also gives some feedback about the quality of your question (e.g. clear resolution criteria), as well as offering alternate questions you might want to ask.

source.id: Double Crux Bot
source.title: Double Crux Bot
source.content:
#project 

https://www.lesswrong.com/posts/ENgwdgdHZ2a6HTWDL/announcing-the-double-crux-bot

GPT-powered chatbot for Slack and Discord that facilitates "double crux" conversations - a conflict resolution technique that helps two people identify the core disagreement underlying their dispute by finding shared cruxes (key beliefs that, if changed, would shift both parties' positions). The bot acts as a mediator to help people "make their reasoning explicit and reflect on the crux of the issue" and "build better inferences about each other's motivations and frameworks so that they can come to a resolution."

source.id: Language Models as Critical Thinking Tools - A Case Study of Philosophers
source.title: Language Models as Critical Thinking Tools - A Case Study of Philosophers
source.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2404.04516
 
Study of 21 professional philosophers examining how language models could serve as "critical thinking tools" rather than just productivity accelerators. The researchers found that current LMs fail as critical thinking partners because they lack "selfhood" (consistent perspectives, memory, beliefs) and "initiative" (curiosity, proactivity, willingness to challenge users), leading philosophers to describe them as "boring," "bland," and "cowardly." The authors propose three new LM roles to better support deep reasoning:
1. the Interlocutor (high selfhood/initiative, challenges and disagrees), 
2. the Monitor (low selfhood/high initiative, provides diverse perspectives), and 
3. the Respondent (high selfhood/low initiative, reacts from specific viewpoints)

source.id: Approaching Human-Level Forecasting with Language Models
source.title: Approaching Human-Level Forecasting with Language Models
source.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2402.18563

LLM system forecasting on competitive forecasting platforms by combining news retrieval, structured reasoning, and fine-tuning techniques to predict binary outcomes. The system automates the traditional forecasting process through three key components: 
1. retrieving relevant information from news sources,
2. generating reasoned predictions, and 
3. aggregating multiple forecasts into a final prediction.

source.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2411.05025

Large-scale survey study examining how researchers currently use LLMs in their research workflows and their perceptions of benefits and risks. The study surveyed 816 verified research paper authors across multiple disciplines to understand usage patterns, demographic differences, and attitudes toward LLM tools in academic work.

The study surveyed 816 verified research paper authors across multiple disciplines to understand usage patterns, demographic differences, and attitudes toward LLM tools in academic work.

source.id: Democratic Policy Development using Collective Dialogues and AI
source.title: Democratic Policy Development using Collective Dialogues and AI
source.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2311.02242

Paper presents a democratic process for developing AI policies through collective dialogues, using AI tools to facilitate large-scale deliberation and consensus-finding among diverse public participants. The system combines AI-augmented group discussions with bridging-based ranking algorithms to identify points of consensus, then uses GPT-4 to translate these into concrete policy guidelines that are refined through expert input and further public feedback.

Funded by [OpenAI Democratic Inputs to AI](https://github.com/openai/democratic-inputs).

source.id: AI-Augmented Predictions - LLM Assistants Improve Human Forecasting Accuracy
source.title: AI-Augmented Predictions - LLM Assistants Improve Human Forecasting Accuracy
source.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/abs/2402.07862

This paper studies how LLMs can serve as assistants to improve human forecasting accuracy, testing two types of assistants - one designed to provide high-quality "superforecasting" advice and another designed to be overconfident and noisy. In a study with 991 participants answering forecasting questions, both LLM assistants significantly enhanced human prediction accuracy compared to controls, with the superforecasting assistant showing up to 41% improvement in some analyses.

source.id: Human vs. Machine -  Behavioral Differences between Expert Humans and Language Models in Wargame Simulations
source.title: Human vs. Machine -  Behavioral Differences between Expert Humans and Language Models in Wargame Simulations
source.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2403.03407

Paper examines how LLMs behave compared to human experts when simulating military crisis decision-making through wargames. The study involved 214 national security experts and compared their responses to AI-simulated teams in a fictional U.S.-China crisis scenario over the Taiwan Strait. The research found that while LLMs showed significant overlap with human decision-making patterns, they demonstrated concerning tendencies toward more aggressive actions and were significantly affected by changes in scenario parameters.

source.id: Sparse Autoencoders for Hypothesis Generation
source.title: Sparse Autoencoders for Hypothesis Generation
source.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.04382

A method that uses sparse autoencoders to automatically generate human-interpretable hypotheses about what features in text data predict certain outcomes (like which headlines get more clicks or what language patterns distinguish Republican vs Democratic speeches). The system works by training neural networks to find interpretable patterns in text, selecting the most predictive patterns, and then using language models to translate those patterns into clear natural language explanations.

source.id: Factored Cognition Primer
source.title: Factored Cognition Primer
source.content:
#project 

https://primer.ought.org/

Tutorial that teaches how to write "compositional language model programs" using factored cognition - a technique that breaks down complex reasoning tasks into smaller, manageable subtasks that can be solved recursively through methods like question-answering and debate. This approach aims to make AI reasoning more transparent and supervisable by decomposing sophisticated thinking into many small, independent tasks that humans can verify.

source.id: Generative Social Choice
source.title: Generative Social Choice
source.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2309.01291

Paper introduces a framework that combines LLMs with social choice theory to enable democratic decision-making on open-ended questions where traditional voting on predetermined alternatives isn't sufficient. The system can generate new consensus statements from diverse participant opinions and predict how well individuals would agree with any statement.

Funded by [OpenAI Democratic Inputs to AI](https://github.com/openai/democratic-inputs).

source.id: Amplifying transformative potential while designing augmented deliberative systems
source.title: Amplifying transformative potential while designing augmented deliberative systems
source.content:
#project 

https://ai.objectives.institute/blog/amplifying-transformative-potential-while-designing-augmented-deliberative-systems

Blog post presenting the "Goldilocks Framework for Augmented Group Intelligence," which proposes principles for designing AI systems that enhance human deliberation and decision-making while preserving authentic human agency. The framework argues that effective AI-augmented deliberation requires balancing two key elements: 
1. participants' ability to understand and steer AI outputs (human agency) and 
2. their commitment to deliberative outcomes 

Higher-commitment decisions requiring correspondingly higher human agency.

source.id: Creating a large language model of a philosopher
source.title: Creating a large language model of a philosopher
source.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/abs/2302.01339

Experiment where they fine-tuned GPT-3 on the works of Daniel Dennett to see if an LLM can produce expert-quality philosophical texts. They tested the "digi-Dan" model by asking both the real Dennett and the AI model ten philosophical questions, then had 425 participants try to distinguish between Dennett's actual answers and the machine-generated responses. The study found that experts often chose the AI's answers over Dennett's actual responses, and on two questions, the AI outputs were selected by more experts than Dennett's own answers.

source.id: Making Artificial Intelligence Work for Investigative Journalism
source.title: Making Artificial Intelligence Work for Investigative Journalism
source.content:
#project 

https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/21670811.2019.1630289

Paper examines how artificial intelligence can be applied to investigative journalism, focusing on the practical challenges and realistic opportunities for AI tools in newsrooms. The research reveals that while AI has enormous theoretical potential for helping journalists analyze large datasets and uncover hidden patterns of public interest, current applications remain limited to relatively simple tasks like document classification and data cleaning.

source.id: LLMediator
source.title: LLMediator
source.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2307.16732

An experimental platform that uses GPT-4 to enhance online dispute resolution by helping parties communicate more effectively and reach amicable settlements. The system offers three key features: 
1. reformulating inflammatory messages to be less confrontational while preserving their core meaning, 
2. generating draft intervention messages for human mediators to guide discussions, and 
3. allowing AI to autonomously mediate certain low-stakes disputes.

source.id: Escalation Risks from Language Models in Military and Diplomatic Decision-Making
source.title: Escalation Risks from Language Models in Military and Diplomatic Decision-Making
source.content:
#project 
https://dl.acm.org/doi/pdf/10.1145/3630106.3658942

Paper examines what happens when LLMs are placed in charge of simulated nations in wargaming scenarios, finding that these AI systems frequently escalate conflicts and, in some cases, even deploy nuclear weapons. The researchers tested five different LLMs controlling autonomous nation agents and discovered that all models showed escalatory patterns, with some developing arms-race dynamics and making decisions based on concerning justifications like deterrence and first-strike tactics.

Paper examines what happens when LLMs are placed in charge of simulated nations in wargaming scenarios, finding that these AI systems frequently escalate conflicts and, in some cases, even deploy nuclear weapons. The researchers tested five different LLMs controlling autonomous nation agents and discovered that all models showed escalatory patterns, with some developing arms-race dynamics and making decisions based on concerning justifications like deterrence and first-strike tactics.

source.id: Contra papers claiming superhuman AI forecasting
source.title: Contra papers claiming superhuman AI forecasting
source.content:
#project 

https://www.lesswrong.com/posts/uGkRcHqatmPkvpGLq/contra-papers-claiming-superhuman-ai-forecasting

Critique of recent academic papers that claim AI systems have achieved "superhuman" forecasting performance. The authors from FutureSearch systematically debunk these claims by identifying major methodological flaws, including inadequate information retrieval capabilities, data contamination, unfair timing advantages, and misleading statistical interpretations that make AI performance appear better than it actually is.

source.id: Forecasting Future World Events with Neural Networks
source.title: Forecasting Future World Events with Neural Networks
source.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2206.15474

Introduces "Autocast," a dataset and benchmark for evaluating neural networks' ability to forecast future world events using thousands of real forecasting questions from public tournaments. The dataset tests language models on diverse topics like politics, economics, and science by simulating historical forecasting conditions—providing only past news articles to prevent information leakage from the future.

(research from 2022)

source.id: ForecastBench - A Dynamic Benchmark of AI Forecasting Capabilities
source.title: ForecastBench - A Dynamic Benchmark of AI Forecasting Capabilities
source.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2409.19839
https://www.forecastbench.org/

Benchmark system that continuously evaluates AI forecasting capabilities using 1,000 automatically generated questions about future events that update in real-time. The system avoids data contamination by using only questions about genuinely unresolved future events, and it compares LLM performance against human forecasters including "superforecasters" who have proven track records. Research found that expert human forecasters significantly outperform the best-performing LLMs (like Claude 3.5 Sonnet).

source.content:
#project 

https://www.lesswrong.com/posts/G4ARgcnFogpqorQgb/ai-doing-philosophy-ai-generating-hands-1

Wei Dai argues that just as current AI systems generate beautiful images but distorted hands, future AI might excel at science and technology while being dangerously incompetent at philosophical reasoning, creating a critical capability gap that requires urgent attention.

source.id: Habermas Machine
source.title: Habermas Machine
source.content:
#project

https://www.science.org/doi/10.1126/science.adq2852

AI system developed by Google DeepMind that uses two fine-tuned language models to mediate group discussions and help people with differing opinions find common ground on contentious issues. The system takes individual written opinions from participants, generates candidate "group statements" that synthesize everyone's perspectives, and iteratively refines these statements based on participant feedback until the group converges on a shared position. Research showed that AI-mediated discussions were more effective than unmediated opinion exposure at causing people to change their minds and reach consensus, with the AI slightly outperforming untrained human mediators.

source.id: Bot Mediation
source.title: Bot Mediation
source.content:
#project 

https://www.americanbar.org/groups/law_practice/resources/law-technology-today/2025/ai-powered-mediation-for-efficient-legal-dispute-resolution/

AI system designed to mediate disputes between parties without human mediators. The platform claims to reduce mediation timeframes from months to days (without having to pay for professional mediation). The company was selected as a [finalist](https://www.techshow.com/2025/02/voting-is-closed-results-are-in-here-are-the-15-legal-tech-startups-selected-for-the-2025-startup-alley-at-aba-techshow/) in the American Bar Association's [TECHSHOW](https://www.techshow.com/) 2025 Startup Alley competition.

source.id: Fine-tuning language models to find agreement among humans with diverse preferences
source.title: Fine-tuning language models to find agreement among humans with diverse preferences
source.content:
#project 

https://proceedings.neurips.cc/paper_files/paper/2022/file/f978c8f3b5f399cae464e85f72e28503-Paper-Conference.pdf

Paper presents a system that fine-tunes an LLM to generate consensus statements that maximize expected approval among groups of people with diverse political opinions. The researchers developed a method where participants provide written opinions on political questions, and an AI system generates candidate consensus statements that aim to find common ground among the group members.

(research from 2022)

source.id: Can AI bring deliberative democracy to the masses?
source.title: Can AI bring deliberative democracy to the masses?
source.content:
#project 

https://www.law.nyu.edu/sites/default/files/Helen%20Landemore%20Can%20AI%20bring%20deliberative%20democracy%20to%20the%20masses.pdf

Conceptual paper analyzes France's 2019 "Great National Debate" as a case study for scaling deliberative democracy, then theorizes two AI-augmented models: 
1. mass online deliberation platforms that use algorithms to cluster and organize arguments among thousands of participants, and 
2. rotating randomly-selected citizen assemblies supported by AI for facilitation, translation, fact-checking, and data synthesis.

source.id: Artifact
source.title: Artifact
source.content:
#project 

https://techcrunch.com/2024/01/18/why-artifact-from-instagrams-founders-failed-shut-down/

Artifact was an AI-powered news aggregation app created by Instagram's co-founders that used machine learning to recommend articles, summarize news stories, and rewrite clickbait headlines into clearer formats. The app featured social elements like commenting and following, creating an engaged community around news consumption, but ultimately shut down in early 2024.

They failed because they couldn't achieve sustainable user growth beyond their initial core community, despite having a quality product that users genuinely engaged with.

source.id: Iterated Decomposition - Improving Science Q&A by Supervising Reasoning Processes
source.title: Iterated Decomposition - Improving Science Q&A by Supervising Reasoning Processes
source.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2301.01751
https://github.com/oughtinc/ice

A human-in-the-loop workflow for breaking down complex question-answering tasks into smaller, interpretable steps for language models. The approach involves systematically decomposing complex tasks, evaluating intermediate results, diagnosing failures, and refining the decomposition through multiple iterations, supported by a visualization tool called ICE.

source.content:
#project 

https://github.com/SentinelTeam/grim
https://www.lesswrong.com/posts/eR69f3hi5ozxchhYg/scaling-wargaming-for-global-catastrophic-risks-with-ai

AI-powered wargaming tool that uses LLMs to simulate complex catastrophic scenarios and help organizations practice emergency responses. The tool functions as a Telegram bot where participants can take actions, request information, and feed data into crisis simulations, with AI serving as both forecaster and game master to create detailed, dynamic scenarios.

source.id: $SL Muses
source.title: $SL Muses
source.content:
#project 
https://www.sltoken.xyz/

The Society Library created AI agents called "Muses" that users can tag on social media platforms to perform reasoning tasks like fact-checking claims and researching topics. Their "Muse of Truth" provides substantive analysis of factual claims with evidence gaps and source references, while the "Muse of Research" pulls resources on requested topics.

The initiative was funded through a community-created meme token ($SL) that was anonymously gifted to the charity, with 50% of holdings donated to support their mission.

source.title: Israel-Palestine Collective Dialogues
source.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/abs/2503.01769

Paper describes a case study of using AI and collective dialogue methods to help Israeli and Palestinian peacebuilders find common ground during the conflict following October 7, 2023. The research integrates LLMs, bridging-based ranking algorithms, and online collective dialogues to identify shared perspectives across divided groups.

source.id: Let’s use AI to harden human defenses against AI manipulation
source.title: Let’s use AI to harden human defenses against AI manipulation
source.content:
#project 

https://www.lesswrong.com/posts/zxmzBTwKkPMxQQcfR/let-s-use-ai-to-harden-human-defenses-against-ai

Blog post proposes using AI systems to discover and catalog human manipulation techniques in order to train "detector-AIs" and humans to recognize these tactics, essentially creating a defensive system against AI manipulation. The approach involves optimizing AIs to persuade humans of both truths and falsehoods, analyzing what manipulation strategies they develop, and then training detection systems to identify these techniques in real-world scenarios.

target.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/abs/2506.06287

Benchmark for evaluating AI agents on complex, multi-step web research tasks that mirror real-world analytical work, using a frozen web environment to ensure consistent and repeatable evaluations. The benchmark tests research capabilities including strategic planning, source credibility assessment, systematic information gathering, and synthesis across contradictory sources through eight different task categories.

target.id: Bench to the Future - A Pastcasting Benchmark for Forecasting Agents
target.title: Bench to the Future - A Pastcasting Benchmark for Forecasting Agents
target.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/abs/2506.21558

Establishes a "pastcasting" benchmark that evaluates AI forecasting capabilities by having LLMs predict outcomes of events that have already happened, using carefully curated web snapshots from before those events occurred. The benchmark addresses a key challenge in forecasting research - the long wait times between making predictions and learning outcomes.

source.id: LLMs Can Teach Themselves to Better Predict the Future
source.title: LLMs Can Teach Themselves to Better Predict the Future
source.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.05253

Method for improving large language models' forecasting capabilities through self-play and outcome-driven fine-tuning, where models generate multiple reasoning traces for prediction questions and learn from which approaches led to more accurate forecasts. The authors demonstrate that smaller models (14B parameters) fine-tuned with this method can achieve forecasting performance comparable to much larger frontier models like GPT-4o.

source.id: How Malicious AI Swarms Can Threaten Democracy
source.title: How Malicious AI Swarms Can Threaten Democracy
source.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2506.06299

Examines how coordinated networks of AI agents ("AI swarms") can manipulate democratic discourse and decision-making through sophisticated influence operations. The authors warn that unlike traditional botnets that simply repeat scripted messages, AI swarms can create thousands of distinct personas that adapt, learn from feedback, and coordinate autonomously to fabricate grassroots consensus and fragment shared reality.

source.id: AI4Democracy - How AI Can Be Used to Inform Policymaking?
source.title: AI4Democracy - How AI Can Be Used to Inform Policymaking?
source.content:
#project 

https://ai.objectives.institute/blog/ai4democracy-paper-how-ai-can-be-used-to-inform-policymaking

Report on how LLMs can be used to process large volumes of public input and aggregate opinions for policymakers, specifically with "[Talk to the City](https://ai.objectives.institute/talk-to-the-city)." The paper examines three real-world case studies (including one on [DAO](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decentralized_autonomous_organization) governance).

source.id: Deep Research Bench - Evaluating AI Web Research Agents
source.title: Deep Research Bench - Evaluating AI Web Research Agents
source.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/abs/2506.06287

Benchmark for evaluating AI agents on complex, multi-step web research tasks that mirror real-world analytical work, using a frozen web environment to ensure consistent and repeatable evaluations. The benchmark tests research capabilities including strategic planning, source credibility assessment, systematic information gathering, and synthesis across contradictory sources through eight different task categories.

source.id: Common Ground
source.title: Common Ground
source.content:
#project 

https://www.dembrane.com/en-US/blog/report-openai-october-2023

AI-powered platform for democratic deliberation that organizes people into small groups to discuss and vote on statements, with an AI moderator (powered by GPT-4) synthesizing new statements from their live video conversations with each other. Statements produced by each group are "cross pollinated" to each other and ultimately synthesized into final consensus statements.

Funded by [OpenAI Democratic Inputs to AI](https://github.com/openai/democratic-inputs).

source.id: Echo
source.title: Echo
source.content:
#project 

https://www.dembrane.com/en-US/products/echo
https://github.com/dembrane/echo

ECHO is a transcription, analysis, and reporting platform designed for multilingual conversations and stakeholder engagement scenarios. It can capture multiple simultaneous conversations in real-time, transcribe them across multiple languages, and use AI to analyze the content and generate insights from the discussions.

source.id: Accelerated Preference Elicitation with LLM-Based Proxies
source.title: Accelerated Preference Elicitation with LLM-Based Proxies
source.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2501.14625

AI system that help people communicate their preferences more efficiently in complex auctions by using natural language instead of technical queries. The system uses LLM-powered "proxies" that learn what people want through conversational interactions and can infer preferences for items not explicitly discussed.

source.id: LLM-Powered Preference Elicitation in Combinatorial Assignment
source.title: LLM-Powered Preference Elicitation in Combinatorial Assignment
source.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.10308

AI system that allows people to express complex preferences through natural language rather than answering technical queries in allocation mechanisms. For example, in course registration, students could provide a single free-text description of their preferences (e.g., "I prefer courses scheduled closely together" or "Course A and B complement each other"), and an LLM proxy would answer comparison queries on their behalf. Experiments testing the system were run using LLM-simulated people.

AI system that allows people to express complex preferences through natural language rather than answering technical queries in allocation mechanisms. For example, in course registration, students could provide a single free-text description of their preferences (e.g., "I prefer courses scheduled closely together" or "Course A and B complement each other"), and an LLM proxy would answer comparison queries on their behalf. Experiments testing the system were run using LLM-simulated people.

source.id: Language models can reduce asymmetry in information markets
source.title: Language models can reduce asymmetry in information markets
source.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2403.14443

Paper presents the "Information Bazaar," a simulated digital marketplace where AI agents powered by LLMs buy and sell information on behalf of principals. The system addresses the buyer's inspection paradox in information markets, where buyers need access to information to assess its value, but sellers need to limit access to prevent theft. The key innovation is that AI agents have dual capabilities: they can evaluate the quality of privileged information and can "forget" unpurchased content, allowing temporary inspection without unauthorized retention.

source.id: AI Tools for Existential Security
source.title: AI Tools for Existential Security
source.content:
#project 

https://www.forethought.org/research/ai-tools-for-existential-security

Paper by Forethought that argues that rather than simply trying to slow down AI development, we should strategically accelerate the development of specific AI applications that help humanity navigate existential risks. 

Three key categories of beneficial AI tools: 
1. epistemic applications to help us anticipate and plan for emerging challenges 
2. coordination-enabling applications to help diverse groups work together towards shared goals
3. risk-targeted applications to address specific challenges

source.id: Democratic Fine-Tuning
source.title: Democratic Fine-Tuning
source.content:
#project 

https://www.meaningalignment.org/research/openai-dft-the-first-moral-graph

LLM-based system creates "moral graphs" by using a two-stage process that aims to uncover shared values underlying political disagreement. A specialized chatbot engages participants in dialogue about contentious scenarios, asking for personal stories and role models to extract the underlying value behind responses rather than collecting ideological commitments like slogans or rules. The system then shows participants stories of people transitioning between different values and asks whether such transitions represent gains in wisdom, creating a graph structure where edges represent consensus about which values are more comprehensive than others

Funded by [OpenAI Democratic Inputs to AI](https://github.com/openai/democratic-inputs).

source.id: Bench to the Future - A Pastcasting Benchmark for Forecasting Agents
source.title: Bench to the Future - A Pastcasting Benchmark for Forecasting Agents
source.content:
#project 

https://arxiv.org/abs/2506.21558

Establishes a "pastcasting" benchmark that evaluates AI forecasting capabilities by having LLMs predict outcomes of events that have already happened, using carefully curated web snapshots from before those events occurred. The benchmark addresses a key challenge in forecasting research - the long wait times between making predictions and learning outcomes.

source.id: How AI Agents Will Improve the Consultation Process

source.content:
#project 

https://ai.objectives.institute/blog/how-ai-agents-will-improve-consultation-process

Blog post describes how AI agents can transform consultation processes by making them more interactive and engaging than traditional surveys. The AI Objectives Institute proposes using different types of AI agents: 
1. "domain experts" to help participants understand complex questions and organize their thoughts, 
2. "professional interviewers" to help refine and improve responses, and 
3. "cross-pollination" agents to help participants exchange ideas and find consensus by synthesizing diverse viewpoints.

source.id: Don't Just Tell Me, Ask Me
source.title: Don't Just Tell Me, Ask Me
source.content:
#project 

https://dl.acm.org/doi/pdf/10.1145/3544548.3580672

Research paper presents "AI-framed Questioning" - a method where AI systems ask users strategic questions instead of directly telling them answers, designed to improve human critical thinking and logical reasoning. The study found that when people were asked questions like "If (premise), does it follow that (conclusion)?" they performed significantly better at identifying logical fallacies in socially divisive statements compared to both receiving direct AI explanations or no assistance at all.
